text: ah sailing being out on the bay with the
wind in your sails yes it's the middle
of winter but I'm talking about another
kind of sailing this is ice boating
better hang on sorry for the shaky ride
folks but I was doing all I could the
other day just to hang on myself when I
caught a ride on a homemade ice boat on
the Great South Bay in Bellport New York
on the south shore of long island they
don't often get ice strong enough out
here for ice boating but they had it
this winter and it's given these folks a
chance to satisfy that need for speed
you know there's not too many things you
can do without a motor that you can go
70 80 miles an hour I can definitely do
it a race in bellport the south bay
scooter club is dedicated to a wooden
hold ice boat originally built by local
duck hunters who wanted something that
could scoot over ice and water it was
also used by rumrunners during
Prohibition I got out on Joel Furman's
boat a homemade plywood shingle on
skates with a sale taken from a sunfish
sailboat this is a popular mechanics
1958 design and they had the plans in
there and I think you could probably
still retrieve it any local library it
doesn't look like much but this little
rig is a lot of fun if you don't mind a
bit of wind chill Joel was chasing boats
and seagulls I was just hanging on
laying flat and trying to dodge the boom
as it swung low overhead how fast can
you go in this uh we were probably doing
close to 60 miles an hour yeah ice
boating is also a long-standing
tradition out on the east end of Long
Island in orient with the locals members
of the Orient ice yacht club we're
getting their kicks on hallux Bay they
had all types of ice boats some nifty
newer ones with lightweight frames and
modern sales tank blew it again okay and
some classic stern steerers this one the
platter you've made in the 1800's with
wood taken from an old local windmill
it was built in eighteen eighty and we
have probably 12 or 15 of these old
boats that go back into the 1800s here
it's really cool that the people loved
ice boating enough to save them and
hopefully they'll be around for many
more generations then there was the
granddaddy the Jack Frost like many ice
boats out here it was lying around in
disrepair for years and finally given to
the club to restore and care for the
gentleman who owned it lists turned it
over to us and we designate a few people
to watch out for it and sale it make
sure it's taken care of these old boats
are classics but there was one smooth
looking Cruiser that caught my eye and
it's skipper mica sebo took me for a
ride Mike told me this was a j-14 he
built himself it's got a springboard in
the front gives it a little bit of shock
absorber this one has a sidecar for
carrying passengers even in light winds
this thing moved along and he later
showed me on his GPS that we were doing
a respectable 30 1.7 miles an hour I
told Mike I had to go in and throw out
but he shot back out on the bay after
all this kind of ice doesn't last
forever
